intro.title: What is the Great Theme Presented in the Bible?
intro.description: There are people who believe that the Bible is a book filled with contradictions since it was written over a very long period, and it has about 40 different authors. However, even though it presents diversity of emphasis and literary styles, there is a great theme that permeates through all its pages: the story of a God that is constantly seeking humans with the purpose of saving them.

4 Without Me they shall bow down among the prisoners, And they shall fall among the slain.” For all this His anger is not turned away, But His hand is stretched out still.

questions.description: Of all the Biblical texts that we could choose to summarize the great theme of the Bible, John 3:16 is the one that best paints the whole picture. God loved the world so intensely that He gave himself, through Jesus, to rescue human kind. The Messiah was to be our Savior.

appendix.appendixContent:
John 1:45

45 Philip found Nathanael and said to him, “We have found Him of whom Moses in the law, and also the prophets, wrote—Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.”

questions.description: This great love story is not only written in the New Testament; it permeates the whole Old Testament as well. In Genesis 3:15 we find the first reference to the coming of the Messiah, when it is said that the woman’s offspring would crush the serpent’s head. This is a symbolic language to speak about the Messiah’s role in the destruction of the work of the Evil one. Philip noticed this truth, and in a conversation with Nathanael, claimed that he had found “the one Moses wrote about in the Law, and about whom the prophets also wrote – Jesus of Nazareth…” (John 1:45). Ever since sin entered the world, God is the one that seeks reconciliation. He is the one who brings the solution for the sin problem, even though He did not cause it.

appendix.appendixContent:
John 17:3

3 And this is eternal life, that they may know You, the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom You have sent.

I John 4:8

8 He who does not love does not know God, for God is love.

questions.description: The reason for God’s tireless work in seeking human beings is his love for each one of us. He is love (1 John 4:8) and desires for all His creatures to have the opportunity to know Him as He really is, so they can be rescued and saved by Him (John 17:3).
